B00021R7CG|4.0|By Dawn's Early Light is one of those movies that could only be made by HBO.  There are no big name TV personalities thrown in for their star value or any ridiculous plot twists that might appeal to the simple minded viewer.  This is one of those movies that came from a time when there was a very real threat for the survival of the world and this movie tells the story of one of those scenarios.    With the dissolution of the Soviet Union control over their nuclear arsenal was, as it is now, suspect.  There was a time when hard line stalwarts from an earlier time (on both sides) believed that a nuclear war was survivable and could be won (remember the duck and cover drills we did where if you hid under your school desk you would survive a nuclear blast or the promise that even after a nuclear blast the US Postal Service would still be able to deliver the mail?).    When renegades from the old Soviet Union fire nuclear salvos at the US (including Washington DC), and with most of the communications and elected leadership of this country decimated, a battle ensues between soldiers who have been trained to follow orders without question and those that might question the validity of those orders when considering the current situation.  We also have a similar battle of wills amongst the top echelon of what's left of the elected leadership of this country and the remaining military leadership advising them.    The cast is superb, the storyline extrememly believable and well thought out and the production values first rate.  This is one of those movies that belongs on people's shelves to be watched from time to time for pure entertainment value.  The viewer will walk away from this movie not in awe of the special effects we see all too often these days, nor will he think he has just seen the latest from Masterpiece Theatre.  He won't won't walk away suddenly endowed with all of the secrets to life but he will walk away knowing he's been entertained and got his money's worthout of this movie.
B00025ETIW|5.0|With their psuedo goth-punk look, unorthodox name, and sketchy if not somewhat juvenile song titles, I'm not ashamed to admit that I wrote this band off, at first, as being another melodramatic emo-trash group that no one except those who FREEBASE emo music and culture into their system could appreciate.     You know, the kind of people who hang out at skateparks with quaffy, psuedo new-wave hairdo's and sit at the top of half-pipes making fun of the fact that you don't know who \\"From Autumn to Ashes\\" is or the fact that you consider \\"Dashboard Confessional\\" and \\"Brand New\\" to be legit emo. You know, those jerks who will rave and rave about a group one minute, but the second said band's video plays on TRL or Fuse they cry \\"SELL OUT\\".    To me, the emo scene is just as bigoted and closed-minded as our forefather's punk scene was 30 odd years ago.    The scene is lame, biased, and, like any other scene, hypocritical at its core, but in all honesty a great deal of the music is very compelling.    Acts like Thrice, Matchbook Romance, and Underoath have put forth great albums with splendid musical arrangments that are complemented by intelligent and complleing lyrics dealing with everything from heartbreak to political angst to the turmoils of the inner self. These talented acts help to positively build upon the image of American music and further help to inspire artists like them.     And with that being said, I can say confidently that My Chemical Romance's \\"Three Cheers for Sweet Revenge\\" can be added to that glorious roster.    With their raging rhythms, crystal leads, and captivating vocals, MCR have proven themselves worthy to be set apart from the more generic and uninteresting emo acts such as Hawthorne Heights or the bland mundanity of the once intriguing Taking Back Sunday. This is a group that you can proudly blare on your stereo or MP3 player and anyone with any real taste in modern rock (be it emo or otherwise) can't touch you.    Probably the biggest standout on this effort is the opening track \\"Helena\\". Whoa! Now this is how you start off an album right! The haunting near whisper of Gerard Way's (vocals) \\"Long ago...\\" along with the single note, palm-muted friction further excentuating his gasps softly coaxes you to draw closer to the song. Then out of no where, a ferocious wall of raw aggresion pummels you into submission. The verses chruning out crunchy, guitar-driven harmonies with Way's voice searing and soaring the whole way. Then comes the chorus, delivering a dramatic tension and intense melody to help bring the song back full circle to the next verse. And the solemn, and almost eery, bridge brings the song back to its epic chorus for an amazing conclusion. The second single off of this CD, it truly stands out as one of the best. An amazing song to get the album up-and-running.    That rapid fire pace is kept going strong with the following tracks \\"Give 'Em Hell Kid\\" and the absolutely exquisite \\"To The End.\\" On the latter of these two tracks, the cryptic storytelling lyrical style and the beatuifully tonal lead progressions played by afroed lead guitarist Ray Toro (or it could possibly be other guitarist Frank Iero, I'll admit I'm not certain) adds a great deal to the desperation and despair that this songs conveys.    This rapid fire progression is only enhanced by the next (and unfortunately titled) track \\"You Know What They Do To Guys Like Us In Prison\\" featuring an uncredited Bert McCracken (of another equally gifted act \\"The Used\\")singing backup (note: the maniacal little chuckle at the end of this song will send a shiver up your spine.)    Then of course, there's \\"I'm Not Okay (I Promise)\\" the track that started it all (well, at least in the eyes of the mainstream anyway :-P.) A very good, upbeat song with a huge climax, roaring vocals and guitars, a lightning quick chorus. Although the guitar solo isn't going to really impress too many people, it still feels very appropriate and does not take anythingaway from the song.    And then, the album decides to slow down a bit with the serene, yet still grandoise \\"The Ghost of You\\". It's blissfully tragic lyrics and meloncholy lead bring out the soul of the song and give it a very deep and tranquil feel. Then the instumrments quickly build up to let out the explosive chorus. I dare anyone not to sing along to Way's gripping lines and wrenching confessions. This song would make an exquisite single. If the Grammy committee weren't run by fuddy-duddy no-nothing fops (Sorry, but these days I don't think that there would be too many people out there who would disagree with that statement. No true artists anyway.) then I would certainly be tempted to regail this song as record of the year, but that's just one 20-something's opinion. A truly mesmerizing tune.    After this brief, yet only slight change of pace, the listener is thrown back into full throtle with another (also unfortunately titled) song \\"The Jetset Life Is Gonna Kill You.\\" Throbbing beats pulsate throughout this song and while it is not the best song on th album, it certainly keeps the listener interested.    But after this song things get a little iffy...    The whisper quiet and solemn \\"Interlude\\" serves as an introductory track to \\"Thank You For the Venom\\", but the pillowy soft nature of \\"Interlude\\" contrasts so vividly from the almost metallic thumping of \\"Venom\\"  that it reall kills off a bit of the effect that the latter song has overall. Which is really a shame becuase \\"Venom\\" is a great track. It's pulse-pounding beat and nail-driving verse make it one of the hardest songs on the whole CD. Not bad a bad tune on it's own, but I recommend skipping \\"Interlude\\" if you can.    And after that song things get very iffy...    The tracks \\"Hang 'Em High\\" and (ugh, these titles!) \\"It's Not a Fashion Statement, It's a Deathwish\\", while not awful songs by any means sound very generic and uninspired. \\"Hang 'Em High\\" starts out well enough with a great verse and interesting lyrics, but the chorus feels a little mismatched with the rest of the song, and the outro is just utter chaos. And \\"Fashion Statement\\" really has no stand out attributes to it at all. It just feels like a very plain (though still not terrible) track.    But the album does get an uplift from another slower paced track \\"Cemetary Drive.\\" With wrenching, painful lyrics and more wonderfully played leads, this song acts as somewhat of a beacon in the darkness of medioocrity that threatens the latter half of this album. The track is not quite as grippng as \\"Ghost of You\\" but it is compelling nonetheless and worthy of a least a few good listens.     The biggest letdown though is the pedestrian final track \\"I Never Told You What I Do For a Living.\\" Nothing sets it apart from the worst of the tracks on this CD and when it's finally over, you're left feeling as if you've come up a little short. A bit ironic that an album that starts off so bombastly would end with such a disappointing fizzle, but it is still not unlistenable by any means. Fans will probably get a kick out of it, but it isn't going to win them any praise on the whole.    \\"Three Cheers...\\" is an album that starts off amazingly, but tapers off a bit towards the end. But don't be scared away by a few mediocre outings. The whole of this album may not be greater than its parts, but the parts are so brilliantly done that you won't mind wading through a few muddy tracks to get to them. A truly enjoyable listen for any fan of rock. A MUST HAVE for anyone into emo of any sorts.    \\"Because if you don't have this album then you're a fake and a loser douchebag communist :-P.\\"     Sorry, I couldn't help myself with that. No matter how quaffed or unquaffed your hair may be (:-D) this is still a good album to have in your library. I don't care how legit or unlegit that may be!     Nootch.

1594200440|3.0|Edward Albee once said of his play &lt;strong>The Goat, or Who Is Sylvia?&lt;/strong> that the first act is a comedy, the second act a drama, the third act a tragedy. When I was about halfway through Lewycka's novel, I thought this was the structure she was attempting, and I thought it was working. Unfortunately, I think matters are resolved a bit too neatly in the end for the book to really work--at least, to really stick with you. I finished it two days ago, and it is already sliding out of my mind. <br /> <br />The book is about an old man, a widower, who wants to marry a much younger Ukrainian woman so she can move to Britain permanently, without fear of deportation. Complications ensue, of course, the most important of which is the personality of the woman in question--she is larger-than-life awful.  <br /> <br />The novel is told from the point of view of the man's younger daughter, Nadia, as she and her sister attempt to disentangle her father from the mess he created. One of the big problems for me us that I didn't feel the narrator had been embued with a lot of personality. She talks a lot about having socialist political beliefs, but it is hard to imagine someone so bland believing anything very strongly. <br /> <br />One of the major subplots of the book is Nadia's prickly relationship with her sister, Vera, who does not share her political views--Vera has spent her life striving for affluency. This subplot and the rest of the novel fit together like two jigsaw pieces that a frustrated child has forced together--but the story of Nadia and her sister was for me by far the strongest part of the book. The most affecting moment of the book, and the only moment I will take away, is a conversation between Nadia and Vera in which they recall a searing childhood memory, and realize that their lives today stem from it. <br /> <br />In the end, this book was only okay: entertaining in the short term, a quick and easy read, but not something I'll remember for very long.

B00005AWMF|5.0|Tonight we have Sade Adu (love the name) in the next room singing about \\"The Sweetest Taboo\\": \\"You have the biggest heart/Sometimes I think you're just too good for me.\\"  Right. Her thin eyebrows are carefully painted on and you know she doesn't have an extra hair on her body. B0009YA37W|4.0|'editors?' fortunately what editors (no article 'the') lack in a quality band name, they more than make up for on their debut album.<br /><br />one of the few bands to actually produce something worthwhile in this whole questionable 'nu wave revival,' editors pack a lot more emotional wallop than nu-wave wannabes like the bravery and the killers. and editors, unlike the bravery and the killers, actually understand what it means to write a decent song.  while a lot of the songs do sound reasonably similar, none of the songs come off sounding repetitive. the album is full of great basslines, jackhammer drumming, and kaleidascopic guitars.<br /><br />tom's vocals are deceptively sincere and heartfelt, in a mortician sort of way. that's not to say, however, that he can't carry a melody, because he sure can--insert comparisons to paul banks, ian mcculloch, and yes, ian curtis here.<br /><br />vocal queue's aside, editors really know how to write a top notch tune. 'munich' (the best track on the album, in my opinion) is a corker -- swirling guitars, deadpan (but sincere)vocals, soaring chorus and the great line 'with one hand you calm me, with one hand i'm still.' it's one of the year's top singles and should get the band noticed on this side of the pond. *should.*<br /><br />'back room' is a very solid and promising debut.  great vocals and lyrics, infectious hooks, solid musicianship. like most decent bands coming out of the UK, editors will, unfortunately, most likely go unnoticed outside snobby indie music circles. but when tom pronounces an edict like 'you'll speak when your spoken to' on 'munich,' one gets the feeling editors will tell YOU when to listen.

B00008EY65|4.0|I'm not a great comic book fan, and I might not have bothered if I'd realized that this was a comic book adaptation. I haven't come across many that I liked. But I liked this one.<br /><br />Its charm is that it doesn't try to take itself seriously. The nervous and worried Dr. Bloom steers his team of soldiers across a hidden Scottish island where the Nazis, led by a supposedly reborn Rasputin, are busy opening a Portal into this world to let nasty demons through (why do people *do* that?! Same reason as they always go down into the basement, I guess...) They more or less thwart the process, but a little red demon pops through. Dr. Bloom tempts it with Baby Ruth bars, and a friendship is born.<br /><br />Off we go, sixty years later. Red has grown up into a red equivalent of the Incredible Hulk. He chain-smokes cigars, stuffs plateloads of pancakes, and gives his new keeper (FBI agent John Myers) a hard time. Nonetheless, a reluctant friendship develops as they fight the plot to kill the hell critters brought back by - of course - Rasputin's girlfriend. (She follows the instructions in a book handed to her before Rasputin meets Grisly Death #2. and brings him back.)<br /><br />It's a fairly standard good-vs-evil kaboom movie, but what I loved about it was the dialogue and the humour. There are a lot of wonderful one-liners and visual puns. Red is so laid-back as to be hilarious, taking each challenge in a \\"oh well, here we go\\" kind of a way. Fighting off the devil dogs in a public train station, he still finds the time to rescue and return a box of kittens to their owner (what the heck is someone doing with an open box of kittens on a train, anyway)? And the romance between Red and Liz, a firestarter who eventually returns from the psychiatric ward after burning it down, does not run smooth, but offers a nice harmony to the rest of the riot.<br /><br />So yes, I enjoyed this in the end. It was fun. It made me laugh. And the special effects were special.

B000001ZS4|5.0|If I lost my entire CD collection tommorow (and it's quite large) first thing on my mind would be to replace Equinox by JMJ. <br />I have this theory that the second attempt or project is very often the best - eg Mad Max  - the second and the best of that film trilogy. <br />Well Its certainly true of Jean Michel Jarre. Oxygene came in 76 and was a breath of fresh air that we still remember fondly. By the time he was making Equinox in 78 he had learned all the lessons and was still so good musically, so intense and energetic in terms of creativity. This work has imortalised him. <br /> <br />My first hearing of this was somewhere unusal - Equinox Part 1 was used on Carl Sagan's Cosmos TV program to depict a last perfect day on Earth when the Sun swells into a red giant and all our oceans dry up signalling the natural end of the world. Well this is the most perfect depiction I've ever seen put to music. It filled me with wonder. <br />  <br />That's exactly what the opening sequence in Equinox always does - profound and powerfull. You can't ignore it. Hair-raising.Yet also beautiful and earthly like the whole of Equinox - right through to the the end which feels like the end of an unforgettable day, tearful and nostalgic. Equinox involkes the seasons, life on Earth in all it's festivities but not merily an observation of nature. This is through the mind of a human and conveys the awarness of the beautiful Earth around him,  a theme to which Jean Michel would return. <br />I recall in 1981 cycling to school with My Sony walkman playing Equinox while all around me was the spring morning and the fog layers over the marshland in the west of Ireland. This is what Equinox is about. Sunrise and sunsets.Nothing about electronics. Go ask JMJ. <br />I always imagine that Peer Gynt himself witnissing the sun rise over the Sahera would have taken his hat off to Equinox. <br /> <br />They say in marketing \\"never change a classic\\". Well to top it all off we have a wonderful albumcover which I hope will never be tampered with by the record company.

B000005IZ8|5.0|Philip Glass gets a bad rap as a one-trick pony and this album is one of the best pieces of evidence that he isn't. True, this record sometimes employs Glass's strong minimalist roots and the familiar ascending/descending melodic lines repeated over and over again like some sort of avant-garde military marching band that are his staple. But most of it is very different, and these sections are usually short and shift rapidly, unlike the epic, 20-minute builds of \\"Koyaanisqatsi.\\" At times it is ambient, at other times rousing and spirited. \\"The Anthem\\" (part two of which was used to great effect in \\"The Truman Show\\" along with selections from Glass's similar \\"Anima Mundi\\" score) manages to be both, and is powerfully symbolic of what \\"Powaqqatsi\\" (\\"life in transformation,\\" if I recall the loosely translated definition of the word) is about. While this record runs a little long, it's brilliantly creative New Age classical and works both with the movie and on its own.
0393324818|5.0|Even though I enjoyed Lewis' Liar's Poker, The New New Thing, and Money Culture, I wasn't planning to read Moneyball. I like to read about money and about baseball, but I don't really care about the economics of baseball. Then I found out that Moneyball is about the Oakland A's, computers, and statistics. I had to read it.<br /><br />Lewis reveals how the A's became a top team even though they have one of the smallest payrolls in baseball. Billy Beane's (the general manager) method of using massive amounts of statistical information tells him what players to draft and what plays to execute under different conditions. The scouts and even the manager have become less important than his small staff of number-crunchers.<br /><br />By following certain statistically-determined rules such as \\"never sacrifice bunt,\\" (the numbers show that historically, it doesn't pay off) the A's have gone to the playoffs year after year. Beane refuses to draft players out of high school, because they haven't faced enough real competition to determine, statistically, if they will be any good. It's only in college and the minor leagues that players compile meaningful stats.<br /><br />There isn't much money in Moneyball, but there is a lot of baseball and a terrific story about an underdog team that beats the odds by using the odds.
B000021Y7X|5.0|What a wonderful, original, and energizing performance. The Talking Heads can PLAY. The original 4-piece (who enter one at a time, gradually building the concert to a fever pitch by the time of \\"Burning Down the House\\") are joined by additional musicians on percussion, keys and guitar (the excitable Alex Weir on guitar is particularly memorable). The music is flawlessly executed and the excitement is stepped up by some crazy dance steps you'll be copying in your living room. The artistry is deliciously strange, and Jonathan Demme is right on as he directs the show (not showing the audience until the very end is an excellent decision I wish more concert movies would make, and thank goodness this concert precedes the MTV style of concert filming, ie. cutting away to a new camera angle every tenth of a second).<br /><br />But what is truly memorable about \\"Stop Making Sense\\" is its energy, the sheer enjoyment the performers are having onstage. It's infectious and it's delightful and even when you have no idea what the lyrics are about, you'll find yourself singing along anyway while tapping your feet. I grew up listening to this album. Now I'll grow old watching this DVD.

B0006399FS|4.0|We live in a world of extremes and blatant contradictions.  Such confusion and, at times, anarchy, extends from the broadest perspective of the social spectrum right down into the very minds and hearts of most individual human beings.  In fact, it's the unsettled nature of the individual that causes the unsettled nature of the society.<br /><br />Embracing the contradictions inherent in our humanity is what U2 is all about.  The understand well that man is a fallen creature, yet at the same time, each person is created in the image of God and therefore has a spark of eternity in their hearts.  Whether or not one agrees with their worldview or even their expressed philosophy and theology, one must agree that the band has a fierce and passionate commitment to their ethic, and they have stayed true to it for more than 25 years.<br /><br />So far, this review is sounding more like a thesis, isn't it?  By now, a few of the more attention-challenged readers have already scrolled past it or angrily indicated their displeasure with me.<br /><br />But the truth is, few of us have the patience to carefully study or digest or thoughtfully consider anything anymore.  This is reflected in many ways; here on Amazon, it shows up in the plethora of 1-star and 5-star reviews.  Very quick, snap judgements get made, and effusive praise is issued or damning vitriol is spewed.  Extremes.<br /><br />Another indicator is in the number of reviewers who are quick to dismiss U2's latest, \\"How to Dismantle an Atomic Bomb\\" as a dud.  One recent reviewer laughably tries to establish his credibility based solely upon the fact that he likes certain \\"hip\\" artists.  I like some of those artists also, and I have virtually every CD they have ever released.  That really doesn't give me any more or less credibility than anyone else.  What we are talking about here is U2, and each review, like each album, should be judged on the merits of its truth, relevance, and helpfulness.  (That same negative reviewer also managed to post his review twice, and asserted that some of the songs on the CD were actually pretty good--why then the 1-star rating?)<br /><br />As for the actual CD itself, it is very good; at times, brilliant.  But other than a few of the obvious songs (\\"Vertigo,\\" \\"City of Blinding Lights,\\" \\"All Because of You\\"), this is not an instantly accessable album.  As some reviewers have indicated, it really takes a few spins for the CD to grow on the listener.<br /><br />But keep on listening, because gradually it begans to dawn on you that this is a very moving, deeply personal, richly felt release that alternately rocks and swings and soothes and heals and comforts and challenges.  What can I say any more wonderful about \\"Sometimes You Can't Make it On Your Own\\" than some of the things that have already been written here?  It is an emotional and aural tour de force.  The visceral impact of the song is both thrilling and devastating.<br /><br />\\"Original of the Species\\" is also a very powerful personal song.  It obviously comes out of a deep place, and it's beautifully done.  I will say that I love \\"Vertigo\\" with its killer buzzsaw guitar work by The Edge and thunderous throbbing bass from Adam Clayton (who is getting better and better with age); and as for Larry Mullen, Jr, he offers further proof that he is simply the best drummer in rock and roll.<br /><br />\\"Miracle Drug\\" is pleasant, though maybe not the most memorable song that U2 has ever done.  \\"Love and Peace or Else\\" is a bit of anonymous growly sludge.  The rest of the CD is pretty much excellent, though maybe not on the level of \\"The Joshua Tree.\\"  One exception is the closer, \\"Yahweh,\\" which captures the grandeur, joy, and epic sweep of earlier triumphs like \\"Where the Streets Have No Name.\\"<br /><br />So, while I can't say this is U2's *best ever* album, I do believe it's exceptionally good, and is one of the best CDs released in 2005.  For many artists, it would be a 5-star triumph.  For U2, it's a stellar album and evidence that their fire still burns bright.5-star triumph.  For U2, it's a stellar album and evidence that their fire still burns bright.   <br /> <br />

I instantly became a fan, and found this CD in my Dad's collection at work (How he had managed to hide the singer who would one day become my NUMBER ONE FAVORITE is beyond me)  It is, without a doubt, the best CD I own. 0385510438|4.0|A writer's maxim: \\"Write what you know.\\" I enjoy Grisham's pure legal thrillers mostly as good page-turners with inside dope on the law. He apparently didn't spend that much of his life being a lawyer, and it's not what he knows best. Small-town Southern life is.<br /><br />\\"The Last Juror\\" returns to the scene of my favorite Grisham, his first, \\"A Time To Kill.\\" I like Grisham better when he colors in his books with Southern life, as he does with these and \\"A Painted House\\", than in his relatively two-dimensional legal thrillers.<br /><br />Other critics here fault this book for meandering. I don't see it that way. What's fine here is his portrayal of life in Clanton, Mississippi, with its eccentric characters, peculiar ways and intense, insular community life. You can taste it and smell it. The central plot element, a brutal rape and murder committed by a scion of an insular local crime family, serves to tie it all together, but at the end of the day, is secondary. This is really a coming-of-age tale about a college dropout, Willie Traynor, who finds himself and grows up after borrowing money from his rich grandmother to buy a failing local weekly.<br /><br />True, some elements never get neatly tied up. At the end you realize the plot wasn't really the star.<br /><br />Traynor, like most Grisham protagonists, has little family. But we never really find out much about the eccentric father from whom he is estranged, nor does anything develop there. We never find out who murders a key witness in the trial. Traynor never finds true love, despite musing about it constantly. And a tense subplot involving a black teenager on the run after dallying with the wife of a white cop is resolved in an offhand manner.<br /><br />What's good here is the character development. You watch Traynor learn newspapering on the fly, grappling with desegregation, local justice, corruption and Vietnam. Traynor develops a friendship with an older black woman, the mother of seven PhDs and the sort of \\"credit to her race\\" needed to anchor the newspaper's first feature stories on black people. Through her eyes he develops a fuller understanding of the town. The lunches they eat constitute an assault of mouthwatering Southern cooking armed by her inexhaustible garden and flanked by desserts of innumerable kinds of cake and pie.<br /><br />Grisham's sense of small-town newspapering is reasonably strong. A small town editor may run a one-man show, personally cranking out a dozen or two stories each week just to fill the paper. He churns the lightest fluff to do so. In a small town, folks love the fluff, as it's about themselves and their friends. (Or enemies.)<br /><br />The ending fails to surprise. The twist was so obvious I thought a second twist would lie beneath it. But this book isn't about neatly tying up one particular crime, even one which concatenates through a decade of the town's life. It's a slice of time and place - a town which changes as good ole boys start growing pot and other good ole boys start smoking it; where the sons of patriotic veterans sour on a seemingly endless war; where a corrupt family begins losing its century-old grip; where schools begin to desegregate; where big-box stores erode downtown business and town-square life; where racial issues aren't solved in a minute but neither devolve into lynchings or cross burnings. Clanton begins easing into the future, as Traynor himself does. Unlike Grisham's many disillusioned young lawyers, Traynor doesn't hate what he does by book's end nor toss it into the dust Gary Cooper-style. He doesn't open a secret bank account in the Cayman Islands. He's just ready to move on.<br /><br />It has the feel of real life, ending when this phase of Traynor's life ends, not when every mystery gets solved. Life's mysteries rarely do.n PhDs and the sort of \\"credit to her race\\" needed to anchor the newspaper's first feature stories on black people. Through her eyes he develops a fuller understanding of the town. The lunches they eat constitute an assault of mouthwatering Southern cooking armed by her inexhaustible garden and flanked by desserts of innumerable kinds of cake and pie.  <br /> <br />Grisham's sense of small-town newspapering is reasonably strong. A small town editor may run a one-man show, personally cranking out a dozen or two stories each week just to fill the paper. He churns the lightest fluff to do so. In a small town, folks love the fluff, as it's about themselves and their friends. (Or enemies.)  <br /> <br />The ending fails to surprise. The twist was so obvious I thought a second twist would lie beneath it. But this book isn't about neatly tying up one particular crime, even one which concatenates through a decade of the town's life. It's a slice of time and place - a town which changes as good ole boys start growing pot and other good ole boys start smoking it; where the sons of patriotic veterans sour on a seemingly endless war; where a corrupt family begins losing its century-old grip; where schools begin to desegregate; where big-box stores erode downtown business and town-square life; where racial issues aren't solved in a minute but neither devolve into lynchings or cross burnings. Clanton begins easing into the future, as Traynor himself does. Unlike Grisham's many disillusioned young lawyers, Traynor doesn't hate what he does by book's end nor toss it into the dust Gary Cooper-style. He doesn't open a secret bank account in the Cayman Islands. He's just ready to move on.  <br /> <br />It has the feel of real life, ending when this phase of Traynor's life ends, not when every mystery gets solved. Life's mysteries rarely do.

B000002N3J|4.0|Many of Madonna's strengths as a songwriter and vocalist are showcased in this compilation of ballads, some previously unreleased.  The most surprising of the new material is her cover of \\"I Want You,\\" which surprisingly holds its own when compared to Marvin Gaye's masterful original.  The Latin-tinged hit single \\"You'll See\\" (#6 Pop, #5 Adult Contemporary) instantly became one of Madonna's best-loved ballads, and it features one of her best vocal performances.  The acoustic-sounding \\"One More Try\\" is also a favorite of mine, probably because the stripped down production places the emphasis on her voice.  This cut really should have been the second single, in my opinion.      The new material helped SOMETHING TO REMEMBER land in the #6 position on the Hot 200, and the well-produced compilation eventually reached Triple-Platinum status in sales.  The previously released material is expertly selected including the big hits (\\"Crazy For You,\\" \\"Live To Tell,\\" \\"Take A Bow\\"), while still giving time to the first-rate modest hits (\\"Rain,\\" \\"Oh Father\\") and lesser-known album tracks (the title track, \\"Forbidden Love\\").  The smash hit soundtrack cuts \\"This Used To Be My Playground\\" and \\"I'll Remember\\" also make their first appearances on a Madonna album.  Every track is presented in it's original album version, which is usually the definite version, although it would have been nice to have had the video mix of \\"Rain\\" included.      The non-chronological sequencing of the songs doesn't bother me since this is a specialty compilation and not a singles anthology.  The only faulty selection is a remix of the early track \\"Love Don't Live Here Anymore\\" (#78 Pop, #16 Dance) which doesn't sit well with the other material (personally, I think either \\"Promise To Try\\" or \\"Inside Of Me\\" would have been much better alternatives).  This is easily forgivable though, when considering the multitude of treasures this chest contains.
B0002BO0AS|3.0|Before you skip over this review because it's not another \\"OMG WOWZORZ THIS ALBUM PWNZ!\\" review, hear me out. I'll admit I'm not a huge metalcore fan, but I am a fan of giving all music a chance and judging it with an unbiased ear. I'm not afraid to admit this album has its moments; it's just that Unearth seems to follow the \\"metalcore pattern\\" for the most part, recycling old riffs, vocal styles, and song structures.     That's not to say the whole album isn't worth listening to, it just feels like an average release, by a fairly average cookie cutter band. You have your generic screaming, your double kick and snare roll with fills, and you have your chord that is played fast and then played slow a little while later. I heard a lot of hype saying these guys were amazing live, and I was interested to see them at \\"Sounds of the Underground\\" this year to see what kid of show they put on. They definitely had some energy, but after already enduring 6 or 7 metalcore bands before them, (I was at the show for Strapping Young Lad, Opeth, Gwar, and Lamb of God mostly) they seemed like every other band that had already hit the stage. (Although Endless, off this album, got the crowd whipped into quiet the circle pit) The metalcore sound seems to have stagnated to a generic pattern that sure, worked for a while, but to become truly special in the music world, you have to come up with something completely different and unique.    Everybody has heard that special album that really sucks them in and takes them by surprise that you experience instead of listen to. I'll search for that feeling anywhere, but it seems like I've come up a little short this time. Rare is the album that is so revolutionary and perfect that you cannot judge the music, but rather be captivated and experience every movement with awe and wonder. (My first feeling of that sort was Opeth) If you're looking for a hard, heavy, metalcore release this will be for you; (although it may only be two progressions different from the last release you bought) Just don't expect anything you haven't heard before.

B00005J6SZ|4.0|A monster smash when released, LIKE A VIRGIN shot straight to #1 on the Hot 200 and has been certified Platinum 10 times over in the US alone.  It remains Madonna's best-selling studio album in the US to date.  This is easily Madonna's most fondly-remembered recording, and, although it's not quite as consistent as her debut, LIKE A VIRGIN is the album that made her a icon.  The title track is still Madonna's second biggest hit (#1 Pop, #29 Adult Contemporary, #1 Dance), and it's still a catchy kitsch classic.  The second smash hit \\"Material Girl\\" (#2 Pop, #1 Dance) is a silly, but endearing stab at the nation's materialism, with Madonna's comically snippy vocals making the whole thing memorable.  Unfortunately, the song branded her with a nickname she has yet to completely shake. <br /> <br />Even though it was a Top Five hit, no one really seems to remember \\"Angel\\" (#5 Pop, #5 Adult Contemporary, #1 Dance), the light-weight third hit.  The massively popular non-single \\"Into The Groove\\" was placed on the B-side of \\"Angel,\\" and sent sales of the single through the roof.  Warner Brothers arguably made a mistake by not releasing \\"Groove\\" as the A-side of the single (it certainly would have hit #1, as it did in the U.K.), however, \\"Angel\\" is still a slinky, if slightly forgettable, pop nugget.  The fourth and final single, the irresistible \\"Dress You Up\\" (#5 Pop, #3 Dance), was also an unstoppable smash, despite being inexplicably included on Tipper Gore's \\"Filthy Fifteen\\" list.  I'm not sure what Mrs. Gore found so offensive in the rather innocent-minded lyrics, but the song has a killer hook that makes such discussions seem pointless. <br /> <br />Madonna was still co-writing heavily with Steve Bray at this point, and two of the album tracks they composed, \\"Over And Over\\" and \\"Stay,\\" are actually stronger than the aforementioned \\"Angel\\" (which was also a Madonna-Bray composition).  The jubilant \\"Over And Over\\" became a fan favorite over the years, and it plays like awarm-up to later Madonna-Bray masterpieces like 1985's \\"Into The Groove\\" or 1989's \\"Express Yourself.\\"  Madonna also sounds very impassioned on the closing \\"Stay,\\" which is perhaps Madonna's best album track from this period.  While these are the only true standouts that the albums offers, Nile Rodgers' slick production makes even the standard-issue filler (\\"Pretender,\\" \\"Shoo-be-doo\\") sound well-crafted and enjoyable.  The only real low point is her cover of Rolls Royce's \\"Love Don't Live Here Anymore,\\" which proves that Madonna had yet to perfect her craft of delivering ballads.   <br /> <br />LAV is 100% pure fun, and even though she has done better work elsewhere, this is the record that the phenomenon known as Madonna will always be remembered for.  As with her debut album, the majority of Madonna's vocals were mechanically altered to sound more high-pitched and girlish, which actually gives the material even more charm.  I think the album would have been improved even further if it had been re-issued with her sountrack hits from `85 (\\"Crazy For You,\\" the aforementioned \\"Into The Groove\\") as bonus tracks, but what's here is the ultimate in mid-eighties trashy synth pop.  This album, more than any other, really captures the spirit of the pop scene of late `84, and it will always hold a special place in my heart for nostalgic reasons.  It has that terrific cover photo too! <br /> <br />NOTE:  In 1985, Madonna made a cameo appearance as a night club singer in the film Vision Quest, and sang two songs.  One of which, \\"Crazy For You\\" (#1 Pop, #2 Adult Contemporary), became an enormous hit.  The other VISION QUEST song, the driving up-tempo stomper \\"Gambler,\\" is a fun dance track that is very much in the mold of her early hits.  As of this writing, \\"Gambler\\" has yet to appear on any of Madonna's proper LPs.  Also in 1985, Madonna made an impressive acting debut in the comedy DESPERATELY SEEKING SUSAN, and contributed the song \\"Into The Groove\\" to the film's soundtrack.  Co-written with Steve Bray, \\"Into The Groove\\" is the ultimate Madonna dance track.  The song was a massive radio hit, but Sire/Warner didn't want to issue the song as a single (they were wanted to only push songs that were on the then-current LIKE A VIRGIN album), so the very popular \\"Into The Groove\\" was only available as the B-side of the \\"Angel\\" single.  It was largely due to \\"Groove's\\" appeal that barely-remembered \\"Angel\\" leaped into the Top 5.
B00004ZAV3|5.0|In November of 2000, The Beatles released their 33rd album entitled, 1. The album contains all of The Beatles' number one hits from 1963 to 1970. B000002NJS|4.0|Possibly the most ballyhooed release of her career, the elcontronica-driven RAY OF LIGHT was being heralded as \\"ground breaking\\" months before the recording even hit stores.  When the release date for RAY OF LIGHT finally did come, I think most honest fans and critics discovered that the press had made too much of the whole electronica issue.  Despite all of the electronic blurbs and gurgles, RAY OF LIGHT sounds less like a Chemical Brothers release and more like a regular Madonna album - albeit a first-rate one.  RAY OF LIGHT features some of Madonna's catchiest hooks and strongest songwriting yet, delivered with a stable and inventive (if a little gimmicky) production courtesy of William Orbit.   <br /> <br />Light also finds Madonna writing with Pat Leonard for the first time in four years, and their collaborations - including \\"Skin,\\" the flop single \\"Nothing Really Matters\\" (#93 Pop, #1 Dance), \\"Sky Fits Heaven\\" (#41 Dance), and the big hit \\"Frozen\\" (#2 Pop, #8 Adult Contemporary, #1 Dance) - provide some of the finest moments on the album.  However, the album's best track (\\"Drowned World/Substitute For Love\\") was co-written with producer Orbit.  Though I find the busy title track (#5 Pop, #1 Dance) to be one of the least successful Madonna-Orbit collaborations, it was also a big hit as a single.  RAY OF LIGHT also features three solid ballads co-written with frequent Stevie Nicks-collaborator Rick Nowels, including the gorgeous hit \\"The Power Of Goodbye\\" (#11 Pop, #14 Adult Contemporary).   <br /> <br />The only complaint I have with the album is Madonna's vocals, which is what ironically drew the most praise from critics and fans.  Her voice now has more range and control, but unfortunately she often seems detached from the material.  No matter how lovely she may sound, there are times I can't help but miss the yearning rasp that was one of the most identifiable characteristics of her voice.  However, this is only a minor quibble and doesn't prevent RAY OF LIGHT from being one of the best albums of the late `90s.

B00005Q66T|4.0|This compilation of Madonna's hits from 1992-2001 does the right thing by including all the official single edits/album versions, and is almost sequenced in chronological order, with only a few tracks presented out of the proper sequence.  The majority of the material that Madonna released during the second decade of her career is first-rate, and the breadth and consistency among the included tracks is quite stunning.  The compilation is very well-balanced between both ballads (\\"Take a Bow,\\" \\"The Power of Good-bye\\") and hardcore dance (\\"Deeper and Deeper,\\" \\"Music\\"), all of which sit together with remarkable comfort on the same disc.  As an added bonus, the delightful \\"Beautiful Stranger\\" finally makes it's first appearance on a Madonna record.    If there is a downside, it would be exclusion of several classic singles.  The missing Top 40 hits (not covered on 1995's ballad compilation SOMETHING TO REMEMBER) include the sophisticated \\"Bad Girl,\\" the Gold-selling single \\"You Must Love Me,\\" and the soundtrack cut \\"American Pie.\\"  Also, it's worth noting that \\"Don't Cry For Me Argentina\\" can't help but seem jarringly out of place next to the other, modern tracks.  I realize that \\"Argentina\\" was a Top Ten hit for Madonna, but the previously-mentioned \\"You Must Love Me\\" or the dance hit \\"Buenos Aires\\" would have made better EVITA selections.      Some fans may lament the fact that there is no previously unreleased material (couldn't she have included a live cut from the \\"Drowned World\\" tour, an exclusive remix, or something?), but the non-stop stream of hits are so appealing that this becomes easily forgiven.  GHV2 debuted at lucky #7 on the Hot 200, but the lack of new hit caused the album to fall off the charts after only 18 weeks.  The disc was able to reach Platinum status, but it became the first Madonna album since 1987's forgettable YOU CAN DANCE not to be certified multi-platinum during it's initial chart run.  However, GHV2 will almost undoubtedly continue to sell strongly over the years as the material it contains is so tremendous and its fantastic to finally have it all in one place.

B00005J6T1|4.0|Madonna's self-titled first album is still an under appreciated recording that she has rarely been able to match.  As fans (both casual and fanatical) often point out, Madonna's singing voice is notably thinner and more transparent on her early recordings with an almost non-existent range.  It should also be noted that the pitch of Madonna's vocals were mechanically altered on this album (as well as the next recording) to sound more girlish, however this actually works with the material rather than against it.  Actually, these early, vocally-limited performances best project her personality and charm - qualities that are unfortunately missing from many of her later recordings.   <br /> <br />The low budget production actually helps give many of the songs a raw, stripped-down feeling (acoustic dance music?), which keeps the album from sounding dated.   In retrospect, \\"Everybody\\" (#3 Dance), \\"Burning Up\\" (#3 Dance) and \\"Physical Attraction\\" (the B-side to \\"Burning Up,\\" which became just as popular as the A-side) sound more like usual rock songs than the over-produced disco tunes that would have been dead on arrival in 1983.  As far as the pop hits are concerned - \\"Holiday\\" (#16 Pop, #1 Dance), \\"Borderline\\" (#10 Pop, #4 Dance), and \\"Lucky Star\\" (#4 Pop, #1 Dance) have remained as enduringly fresh as the day they were recorded.   <br /> <br />The remaining two tracks (the only ones that weren't released as singles in some format) are also worthy, if not as meticulously produced.  This album was a real sleeper hit, finally reaching the Hot 200's Top Ten a full year after it's release!  It eventually peaked at #8 and has since reached a very impressive Quintuple-Platinum status in sales.  MADONNA also spent a whopping 168 weeks on the Hot 200, more weeks than any of Madonna's other albums.
0553573403|5.0|Let me say that I started out at the age of 11, reading the Lord of the Rings. Someone should have told me to wait a few more years, because it was all downhill from there. Eddings, Terry Brooks, Goodkind, Robert Jordan -- they all draw heavily from Tolkein and thereby become \\"fantasy through the eyes of this author after he read LOTR.\\"<br /><br />I stopped reading the Wheel of Time after finishing the 150(!) page prologue of Book Five and having no idea what the heck is going on. I cracked open Brooks' Jerle re-hash and it almost put me to sleep. I felt as though my love of fantasy had lived and died with Tolkein, so I moved on. Then a couple of my co-workers insisted I check out Ice and Fire.<br /><br />So I did, and it was slow, and  I was hundreds of pages in, and there appeared to be no over-arching plot line -- just political intrigue. However, the characters were very well defined, particularly Tyrion Lannister, who's like the Jeremy Piven of this series. There wasn't silly magic all over the place, no cheesy prophecy, no obvious Messiah character, no browbeating portents of supernatural doom, no Gandalfian mentor, no Font of Dark Evil nemesis -- in other words, Ice and Fire is more like historical Medieval fiction than genre exercise, and cripes, and hadn't realized how much the genre needed classical drama until I read this.<br /><br />There is profanity, sexual situations involving minors, gruesome depictions of violence, ribald humor, et cetera, so it's not for the little ones. Not that they'd want to dip into an 800+ page paperback novel. This thing is a doorstop. But like I said, even though the main plot arc is glacial, it's a pleasure to read because the characters feel like *people* and locations feel like *places*. He creates vibrantly different cultures, despicable (but not generically evil) characters, and a nuanced narrative that is obviously the product of his having been around the block more than a few times.<br /><br />If The Game of Thrones doesn't deserve five stars, I don't know what fantasy novel does. Unlike other fantasy novelists I could name, I really get the impression that Martin respects his audience and is not out to milk them, despite the fact that this series is supposed to be six novels in length.Thrones doesn't deserve five stars, I don't know what fantasy novel does. B000002NAK|3.0|With so many highlights, why does the soundtrack to Madonna's greatest screen performance always feel slightly disappointing after a listen?  This a problem common with most of Andrew Lloyd Webber's work:  many good individual songs that fail to make a cohesive show.  Webber is a composer many theater enthusiasts (i.e. snobs) hate because he writes theater songs as if they were pop radio hits.   <br /> <br />While he's no match for intellectual brilliance of Sondheim (though neither is any other modern composer), I personally love many of the songs Webber has composed - from \\"Memory\\" (from CATS) to \\"The Music of the Night\\" (from THE PHANTOM OF THE OPERA) as well as many others - however, I seldom like his plays when taken as whole.  The same goes for EVITA:  even though the album is full of great tracks, it really doesn't gel into a completely satisfying unit.   <br /> <br />But that doesn't really matter in the end, because most listeners will be justifiably thrilled with Madonna's impressive vocal performance.  Madonna gives the definite renditions of \\"Buenos  Aires\\" (#3 Dance), \\"High Flying, Adored,\\" \\"Another Suitcase In Another Hall,\\" and \\"Rainbow High,\\" however she sounds a little shaky on \\"Don't Cry For Me Argentina\\" (#8 Pop, #21 Adult Contemporary, #1 Dance).  Maybe it was because \\"Argentina\\" is such a well-known number, but, for whatever reason, Madonna sounds nervous in her delivery.   <br /> <br />This is forgivable, however, thanks to her other stunning song renditions, including the newly written, Gold-selling \\"You Must Love Me\\" (#18 Pop, #15 Adult Contemporary), which ranks as one of her best singles.  The public supported Madonna's labor of love by sending the double-disc set to #2 on the Hot 200.  Impressively, the album achieved Quintuple-Platinum status in sales, making it Madonna's most successful album of the nineties.  It may not be the masterpiece it strived to be, but the EVITA soundtrack is one of Madonna's most impressive releases to date. <br /> <br />NOTE:  Of special interest to fans are the two singles that Warner Bros. released to promote the Evita soundtrack, both of which featured alternate versions of both songs.  The single version of \\"You Must Love Me\\" (#18 Pop, #15 Adult Contemporary) features the exact same vocal performance from the soundtrack, but is slightly remixed with a more \\"pop\\"-sounding arrangement, including a beautiful new string introduction (the soundtrack cut begins with Madonna singing a cappella).  For the release of the soundtrack's best-known song, the now-standard \\"Don't Cry For Me Argentina\\" (#8 Pop, #21 Adult Contemporary, #1 Dance), Madonna and Warner Bros. surprised everyone (and outraged Weber purists) by releasing a drastically altered remix of the song, entitled the \\"Miami Mix.\\"  The \\"Miami Mix\\" of \\"Argentina\\" transforms the dramatic ballad into a campy dance club epic, and is further boosted by Madonna's rerecorded vocals on the chorus.  I thought Madonna sounded somewhat nervous and quivery on the original ballad version of \\"Argentina,\\" however, she sounds much more confident and impassioned on the \\"Miami Mix\\" remix of the song.  Both of these alternate versions are responsible for getting the singles on the airwaves and landing the songs in the Top 20 on Billboard's Hot 200, and they also contributed to the Multi-Platinum sales and high chart position of the EVITA soundtrack.  Although, ironically, neither remix was actually included on the soundtrack album that they promoted.

B00000DHRX|4.0|A well done hits compilation, spread across two discs and including some interesting rarities and new songs.  The songs are divided up in non-chronological order, with ballads on one disc and dance tracks on the other.  I personally would have preferred the tracks to have been sequenced chronologically, but the current sequencing is satisfactory, and isolating the dance tracks leaves you with a great party disc.  Just for the record, no songs with Wham are included (\\"Careless Whisper\\" and \\"A Different Corner\\" were released as solo songs), the UK hit \\"Older\\" is missing, and the hit version of \\"I Want Your Sex\\" has been replaced with the \\"Part II\\" reprise of the song.  The remainder of the songs are all presented in their original single versions, which makes it a great buy even if you have all of Michael's proper albums.    The US and UK versions of the compilation have slightly different track listings.  The newly-recorded dance single \\"Outside\\" (#2 UK) is present on both version, but the stirring cover of Stevie Wonder's \\"As\\" (#4 UK), with Mary J. Blige) is only found of the UK issue.  The UK version also includes a 1997 remix of \\"The Strangest Thing\\" and the killer B-side \\"Fantasy,\\" but inexplicably omits the smash hit \\"Monkey,\\" which is on the US version.  Both versions included two generous booklets with lyrics and many beautiful photos of Michael.  Given the inclusion of the few rare tracks, I suggest listeners pick up the UK version (after all, \\"Monkey\\" is easily found on the Faith album).  Either way you go, however, this is a great compilation that includes some of the best pop singles of the eighties and nineties.
B00007FOMP|5.0|Marvin Gaye in the late 60's and early 70's was an important artist in the Motown family. His soulful voice, combined with his passion and energy in his songs, made him a shining star. However, closing in on age 30, he was ready to try something new, expand his artistic vision, something that never ever was done in the Motown factory. Berry Gordy was pretty clear on what he wanted: chart topping, radio playing, record selling hits. He hired singers to sing these songs, and writers to write these songs. The songs were light on meaning, heavy on melody, and always loaded with hooks. Gaye was itching just like the Beatles in the 60's did to move past simple songs. He wanted to write his own material, and sing what was really on his mind. Finally, in the early 1970's, he released \\"What's Going On\\", an album that Gordy was very hesitant in releasing. What ended up happening was history changing. <br /> <br />\\"What's Going On\\" is a concept album, in which Gaye co-wrote and sang songs about many of the issues of concern at the time. The title track deals with his brother Frankie coming home from the Vietnam War and what they thought about the whole war. \\"Mercy Mercy Me (The Ecology Song)\\" tackles environmental issues that were going on at the time, including the increase in nuclear power. \\"Inner City Blues (Make Me Want to Holler)\\" talked about the increasing problems in the city, with drugs, crime, etc. These three songs hit the Top 20 to the surprise of Gordy, and in the process, it helped other Motown artists (mainly Stevie Wonder) in getting their artistic freedom to try new things with their music. <br /> <br />The music is meaningful, and it makes you think. It's smooth, soulful beat reminds me of walking through a park on Sunday morning. Gaye broke down the doors that all R & B music had to be about fluffy, bubblegum topics and that artists could create their own sound and meaning. Gaye redefined himself as a socially conscious singer/songwriter with this album, andwould later define himself also as a highly romantic artist with \\"Let's Get It On.\\" It helped in sealing the legacy of the late Marvin Gaye. Get a piece of music changing history today.
B000002LLC|3.0|First off, this album is definitely worth owning as it is the only place to get the original mix of the smash \\"Vogue\\" (#1 Pop, #23 Adult Contemporary, #1 Dance), with the original \\"finger-snap/bongo-drum\\" introduction intact.  The version of \\"Vogue\\" that was included on THE IMMACULATE COLLECTION featured a needlessly extended intro (and also dropped some of the killer synth lines), while the single/radio version of the song skipped the introduction all together.  The version featured here (which is the version that was used in the music video) is the definite mix of the classic Shep Pettibone collaboration, and it is arguably THE quintessential Madonna single.  As of this writing, I'M BREATHLESS is still the only album where \\"Vogue\\" can be found in it's original form.    Besides \\"Vogue,\\" the album's other Madonna-written material (the rest co-written with Pat Leonard) is in the form of a pseudo-concept album, attempting to capture the witty dancehall material of the 1930's, as performed by Madonna as DICK TRACY's club chanteuse Breathless Mahoney.  On this level, Madonna demonstrates surprising versatility as both a songwriter and a singer as she whips up a marvelous torch song in \\"He's a Man,\\" a sentimental-yet-simmering ballad with \\"Something to Remember,\\" and goofily brilliant novelty tunes like \\"Back in Business\\" and the single \\"Hanky Panky\\" (#10 Pop).  Sure, the overall sound feels less like 1930's big band and more like Broadway-pop circa 1990, but that's part of the fun.  Of the six Madonna-penned numbers, only \\"Cry Baby\\" fails to engage, and perhaps should have been dropped from the track selection.     The album also contains two songs by co-written Andy Paley, and, although these tracks are in the same vein as the Madonna/Leonard material on the album, they are surprisingly not as much fun.  The Brazilian-flavored \\"I'm Going Bananas\\" is cute enough for it's brief 90-second runtime, although it's meager success stems more from Madonna's uncanny Carmen Miranda impersonation than from the actual number.  Paley's \\"Now I'm Following You\\" is one of only four songs on the album to have actually been featured in the film DICK TRACY (in a version performed by Paley himself, however, not the version on this album sung by Madonna and Warren Beatty), although it's actually rather pedestrian (though harmless) fluff.  The version of the song included on I'M BREATHLESS is given more mileage by some amusing interplay by Madonna and then-current beau Warren Beatty, as well as some humorous production gimmicks in the \\"Part II\\" remix of the song.        Where Madonna really impresses fans, however, is on the three numbers written by Steven Sondheim, unarguably one of the finest songwriters of his generation (the Sondheim tracks are also incidentally the remaining three of this disc's four tracks that actually appear in the film DICK TRACY).  Madonna's studio rendition of the Oscar-winning vamp classic \\"Sooner or Later\\" is sizzling and touching, although I actually prefer the brassier, Monroe-like live performance of the song that Madonna performed on the 63rd Annual Academy Awards.  Madonna also rises to the challenge in delivering some of Sondheim's trademark rapid-fire wordplay on the terrific \\"More,\\" a delightfully satirical number that successfully puts Madonna in the comedic Judy Holiday territory that she has always professed to aspire to as a performer.  Of the Sondheim material, only \\"What Can You Lose\\" fails to completely connect, largely due to the fact that the song is pitched too high for Madonna's low register, and it ends up becoming solo piece for duet partner Mandy Patinkin (albeit, a very pretty one).     Due to the success of \\"Vogue\\" and \\"Hanky Panky,\\" I'M BREATHLESS shot straight to the #2 position on the Hot 200, and managed to achieve Double-Platinum status in sales.  Madonna, in general, was virtually unstoppable in 1990, and this album is a great snapshot of this milestone year for the entertainer.  With the seemingly-constant airplay of the \\"Vogue\\" video and single, her well-received supporting turn in DICK TRACY, and the mammoth BLONDE AMBITION tour (which is still probably her greatest artistic achievement), this was also one of the few times that Madonna was a darling of the critics.  A very good concept recording that finds the diva stretching outside her usual fare and successfully delivering something different, I'M BREATHLESS is good fun.

B000002MUW|4.0|After the immense public backlash following the SEX book and the album EROTICA, Madonna made the commercially-wise decision to evolve in her style a little more before releasing her next album.  She decided to continue experimenting with the R&B elements she heavily adopted on EROTICA, however she added a warmer and more humanistic slant to material.  It could be argued that Madonna may have gone a little too far with the conservatism on this release, and (except for perhaps \\"Human Nature\\") she steers clear of any possible controversy.  The disc lacks the hard-hitting sass of EROTICA, but it's so fresh and tuneful that I seriously doubt most listeners will mind.  The album was another success for Madonna, peaking at #3 on the Hot 200 and quickly going Double-Platinum - excellent for an recording artist in the second decade of her career.   <br /> <br />The first single, the sizzling \\"Secret\\" (#3 Pop, #2 Adult Contemporary, #1 Dance), was a smash hit right out of the box, and the gorgeous \\"Take A Bow\\" (#1 Pop, #1 Adult Contemporary) remains the most successful single of Madonna's career.  The Bjork-penned semi-title track \\"Bedtime Story\\" (#42 Pop, #1 Dance) was an adventurous choice for a single, but it received virtually no airplay and became Madonna's first song to fail to reach the Top 40.  That's a shame, because it's as daring and creative a song as any mainstream artist released in the `90s.  I personally find the album's fourth single, the bitingly funny \\"Human Nature\\" (#46 Pop, #2 Dance), to be the disc's weakest number, however, it too is well crafted and blends into the rest of the album surprisingly well. <br /> <br />However, the singles aren't from the disc's only highlights, as, with BEDTIME STORIES, Madonna never takes a wrong step.  The slight-endearing light-dance cuts \\"Don't Stop\\" and Survival\\" and the soulful ballads \\"Forbidden Love\\" and \\"Love Tried To Welcome Me\\" are nearly as strong as the singles, and they settle in well with one another. The album is acceptable in length (around 50 minutes) and it features a set of pretty consistent songs.  As with LIKE A PRAYER, BEDTIME STORIES is a showcase for Madonna's songwrtiting, which perhaps her greatest strength.  Madonna is possibly the most underrated lyricist of her generation, and this album offers an abundance of evidence for this claim.  Of special note is the unusual ballads \\"Inside Of Me\\" and \\"Sanctuary,\\" which are absolutely brilliant compositions, and are two of the most poetic pop songs ever composed.
B00005JMJ4|1.0|How much thought was put into this movie? Really? Was showing the streets of Japan all this movie wanted to do? The movie is simple: two Americans with typical problems about being depressed, pointlessly wandering around Japan while nothing worth caring about happens. It's as if the story was made up as it went along. There was no real script it seems. To say the whole film was nothing but an expensive home video of tourists wouldn't be far off. Literally, this is nothing but people on vacation, who happen to be sad, doing stuff together, and then presto, we have a real winner because Scarlett Johanssen's panties are shot tastefully by a bigshot director's daughter. What a real \\"thought-provoking\\" \\"indie-art\\" flick huh?
B000002MFN|4.0|EROTICA contains so much of Madonna's very best work, it's a shame that there has always been such a negative stigma attached to it.  The album came out simultaneously with Madonna's controversial SEX book and the unintentionally hilarious box office bomb BODY OF EVIDENCE.  Though the album peaked at #2 on the Hot 200 and was certified Double-Platinum, a huge backlash ensued shortly after it's release which tarnished the disc's image in the minds of many.  However, EROTICA represents a very intriguing time in Madonna's career, and it seems like it's time for a reevaluation of it's worth.  Madonna was entering into a risky, non-commercial territory with this release, and the result of her venture is a deeply personal, occasionally frustrating, and always fascinating recording.  There are also some genuinely breathtaking moments here, and that's what makes it essential for anyone with even a passing interest in the singer.   <br /> <br />The smash title track (#3 Pop, #1 Dance) is similar to 1991's \\"Justify My Love,\\" but with a much better melody and an absolutely killer hook.  The eerily distorted sounds, the bizarre instrumental loops, and Madonna's contrasting vocals (a gravely sing-speak style on the verses, which leads into a shrilly soprano for the chorus) are all factors that create the most overtly sensual, yet slightly disturbing single in Madonna's catalogue.  Even if you don't particularly like this song, I'm certain you won't soon forget it.  Madonna also successfully flirts with some new genres of music, including bass-heavy hip hop on \\"Waiting\\" and \\"Did You Do It,\\" reggae with the terrific \\"Why's It So Hard,\\" and even some light jazz with the misunderstood \\"Where Life Begins\\" and the beautifully understated \\"Secret Garden.\\"  Surprisingly, Madonna handles all of the above styles expertly, without ever sounding awkward or forced.  <br /> <br />Madonna is back on familiar ground with the unabashed disco of \\"Deeper and Deeper\\" (#7 Pop, #1 Dance), which is perhaps her best pure dance cut of the nineties, and it remains one of the ultimate club anthems.  The seemingly confessional \\"Bad Girl\\" (#36 Pop, #1 Dance) was the third single, and while it became her first single to fail to crack the Top 20, it remains perhaps Madonna's most criminally underrated songs.  A fatalistic semi-ballad that details the unhealthy addictions and empty affairs of it's titular character, \\"Bad Girl\\" ranks along with \\"Live To Tell\\" and \\"Like A Prayer\\" as one of Madonna's most mature and sophisticated compositions.  The simple, but effective \\"Words\\" overcomes any lyrical clichs with it's delightfully off-kilter arrangement, while the elegant \\"Rain\\" (#14 Pop, #7 Adult Contemporary) is a lovely ballad that would make the late Karen Carpenter proud.   <br /> <br />Unfortunately, the remaining tracks on EROTICA, while listenable, are not nearly as successful.  \\"Thief Of Hearts\\" is an uninspired rip-off of Blondie's much more vicious classic \\"Rip Her To Shreds,\\"  the international single \\"Bye Bye Baby\\" is brittle and annoying, and AIDS ballad \\"In This Life\\" is well-intentioned but trite.  Madonna's sensual cover of Peggy Lee's \\"Fever\\" fares better, but the dull album version pales in comparison to the excellent remix of the song that was featured in the international music video.  These mediocre tracks often halt the disc's momentum, therefore preventing it from being the hard-hitting masterpiece it could have.  Perhaps Erotica also suffers from being Madonna's first true album of the CD area - like many early-'90s discs, it's simply too long.  If Madonna hadn't been so concerned about filling up the entire 70-plus minutes of a compact disc, maybe the second tier numbers would have ended up cut from the final track listing.  She then could have released a shorter, more consistent album.  Still, Erotica has much to recommend it, and it definitely one of the most interesting mainstream releases of the early nineties.  <br /> <br />NOTE:  In early 1994, Madonna chalked up another big soundtrack hit with \\"I'll Remember\\" (#2 Pop, #1 Adult Contemporary), from the box office flop With Honors.  The single was also Madonna's first new collaboration with Pat Leonard in five years.  Like Madonna's 1992 soundtrack ballad \\"This Used To Be My Playground,\\" \\"I'll Remember\\" is a top-notch ballad that is sentimental in only the best way.
B000006TRV|5.0|The sound track \\"The Wall\\" is most probably the best rock album in history!  This CD combines rock, theatre, and an alter state of conscienceness!  I highly reccomend this musical journey through Roger Waters mind.
B00004X01U|2.0|The title song (#1 Pop, #1 Dance) became her 12th #1 hit on the Hot 100, and is the third-biggest single (behind \\"Take A Bow\\" and \\"Like A Virgin\\") of Madonna's entire career.  The track is a swirling, synth-heavy mix of hard beats, blubbering vocals, and a killer hook.  In other words, it's a terrific single, and easily the best dance recording of 2000.  Unfortunately, the same cannot be said for it's album counterpart, full of loud synthesized noises, but little of the strong songwriting that made RAY OF LIGHT a tremendous success.   <br /> <br />Madonna and  Mirwais Ahmadzai produced and wrote the majority of the tracks, and it's clear that they don't have enough ideas to fill up an entire album.  The two try to blend traditional music in untraditional ways on \\"I Deserve It\\" and the hit \\"Don't Tell Me\\" (#4 Pop, #1 Dance), but the two numbers end up sounding awkward and endless.  This mixing folk/country elements with British trip-hop is an undeniably interesting idea, but it just doesn't work, or at least not in the hands of Madonna and Ahmadzai.   <br /> <br />Another reason MUSIC isn't any more successful is because the songwriting is surprisingly weak.  Madonna had transformed herself into a top-notch lyricist on LIKE A PRAYER, BEDTIME STORIES, and RAY OF LIGHT, but here she offers some of the most empty, nonsensical lyrics she's ever come up with.  The prime offender is the tuneless \\"Paradise (Not For Me),\\" where Madonna recites increasingly silly lyrics like \\"There is a light, above my head.\\"  Okay!  Madonna and Ahmadzai also use the vocoder way too much, most obviously on the grating \\"Nobody Perfect,\\" which runs the device into the ground.   <br /> <br />Other than \\"Music,\\" the only Madonna-Ahmadzai track that I like is the over-the-top \\"Impressive Instant,\\" which is so relentlessly giddy that all of the overboard production gimmicks and silly lyrics actually work.  William Orbit also climbs aboard for three tracks, but only the mournful \\"Gone\\" even comes close to the level of quality that he and Madonna achieved with RAY OF LIGHT.  The Madonna-Orbit production \\"Runaway Lover\\" is merely adequate, while the charmless \\"Amazing\\" is nothing but a blatant copy of their own superior hit \\"Beautiful Stranger.\\"  One can't help but wonder why Orbit-produced soundtrack cuts \\"Beautiful Stranger\\" and \\"American Pie\\" weren't included as bonus cuts, which would have made the album indefinitely better.  <br /> <br />However, there is one moment of greatness (again, beside the title track) found on this otherwise disappointing release.  The minor hit \\"What It Feels Like For A Girl\\" (#23 Pop, #27 Adult Contemporary, #1 Dance), the only track produced with Guy Sigsworth and Mark \\"Spike\\" Stent, is well-written song that is produced and performed with great restraint.  After hearing the rest of the album, that is very refreshing indeed.  This album became Madonna's fourth album to hit #1 on the Hot 100 (and her first since 1989's LIKE A PRAYER), but it didn't remain on the charts as long as RAY OF LIGHT did.  It managed to reach Double-Platinum status in sales, but couldn't match LIGHT's Quadruple-Platinum success.
